div.p: I received your postcard of the 24th this afternoon. I fear that you do not quite enter into all my difficulties and troubles, least of all those connected with my Basque studies. These only lead to melancholy. I am not content with any of the persons with whom they have brought me into correspondence or conversation, though many of them are in most ways very estimable persons, and yourself among the best. At any rate you do not flatter me falsely as some have done. I thank you for the good will shewn in your letters on my behalf to messrs. Gaston Paris, Gustav Gröber, and W. L. Courtney. My Basque Ahasuerusism (a very original and rather illomened description of my hobby) has only placed me in perpetual financial difficulties, like that which is afflicting me at present. My family are rich, but do nothing for me beyond giving me a feeble pittance on condition that I do not set foot in the British iles. They never even write to me. So I am continually being asked if I am a political exile, a fugitive from justice, and so forth. M r Bronta, who knows the Luxembourg language, and gave me Lentz poems, when I introduced him to Azkues class in 1891, is here. He saw me from a traincar and wrote to Poste Restante to ask to see me. Are Sybaris and Kumae in South Italy Basque names?
